document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

subSubSection.paragraph:
Anthophora curta var. petrophila Cockerell, 1905: 15
( holotype : ♀ ; Rock Creek, CA, USA ; coll. Davidson; CASENT, type 15467).

Distribution. See Fig. 24 . Found throughout much of west, often somewhat montane in hottest areas, occupying much broader range of environments in colder areas, less montane. Present in USA : California , Nevada , Utah , Arizona , New Mexico , Colorado , Idaho , Wyoming , likely Oregon , likely Montana , possibly Oklahoma ; Mexico : Baja California Norte, Chihuahua , likely Sonora , possibly Coahuila . Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 3482 specimen records: 17 ecoregions total: Colorado Plateau shrublands (1654=47.5%), Mojave Desert (855=24.6%), Great Basin shrub steppe (456=13.1%), Chihuahuan Desert (214=6.1%), Sonoran Desert (173=5%), California montane chaparral and woodlands (37=1.1%), Colorado Rockies forests (22≤1%), California coastal sage and chaparral (21≤1%), Snake-Columbia shrub steppe (11≤1%), Sierra Nevada forests (10≤1%), Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests (9≤1%), Wasatch and Uinta montane forests (5≤1%), Arizona Mountains forests (5≤1%), California Central Valley grasslands (4≤1%), Western short grasslands (2≤1%), California interior chaparral and woodlands (2≤1%), South Central Rockies forests (1≤1%).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 24. Distribution of
Anthophora petrophila
. Generated with 3482 specimen records from 941 locations.

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology. Recorded from March–November, highly dependent on region, usually emerging earlier in warmer regions. Bivoltine in most areas, only univoltine at highest elevations, and potentially trivoltine under ideal conditions.

Nesting biology.
Anthophora petrophila
has been collected nesting in horizontal and vertical, hard-packed silt deposits by the first author. Phil Torchio also collected this species nesting in vertical, silty banks, although this was never published and the site could not be located due to unsufficient notetaking. At one new site near Moab, Utah , it was confirmed that this species reuses old nests via observation that a single female was using a nest in which six unprovisioned cells were excavated. Further details on these new records will be presented in a subsequent review of the group’s nesting biology.

Floral specialization. Reported as a specialist on
Asteraceae ( Moldenke & Neff 1974 )
. Appears true, with great breadth, likely enabling its large distribution. Primary recorded visits by 1007 females include: Family Asteraceae (86%); Genus
Ericameria
(28%),
Chrysothamnus
(13%),
Chaenactis
(12%); Species
Ericameria nauseosa
(23%). 1666 total floral records from 25 families include:

Comments. This is the most widespread, common species of A . (
Micranthophora
). In part a consequence of its commonness, a very rare labral deformity was recently discovered and described from this species; the specimen’s labrum was reduced to a mere dot and its clypeus was enlarged, encircling the reduced labrum ( Orr & Tripodi 2017 ). The wide range of this species raises the question of whether it may, in fact, be multiple species. Although additional work may demonstrate that it is a species-complex, morphological and preliminary infraspecific molecular work have not supported this. Note that this species is very commonly confused with
A . exigua
by prior authors, and that MCO determinations prior to 2013 may also be suspect. Several males of this species have been separately observed resting overnight on plants via their mandibles (typically on Asteraceae or Asteraceae-adjacent plants).
